vectorData.altText: That's right! Chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla secrete epinephrine and norepinephrine in response to input from the lateral horn cells of the spinal cord.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.

Like neurons of autonomic ganglia, chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla are derived, embryologically, from neural crest cells. A reticular fibre stroma supports knots of chromaffin cells interwoven with a dense network of sinusoidal capillaries. Chromaffin cells can be considered modified sympathetic ganglionic neurons that have lost their cell processes, and secrete their product into the surrounding interstitial fluid. 
Chromaffin cells produce catecholamines, either epinephrine or norepinephrine. Of the catecholamines produced by the adrenal medulla, 80^%^ is epinephrine, and 20^%^ is norepinephrine. Catecholamines, being amino acid derivatives, are hydrophilic, and are stored in lipid-enclosed vesicles prior to release.

Chromaffin cell secretion is controlled by sympathetic preganglionic neurons arising in the lateral horn cells of the spinal cord. Sympathetic outflow increases in times of stress, and promotes the release of catecholamines from the adrenal medulla which contributes to the “fight or flight” reaction. 
Norepinephrine causes vasoconstriction in non-essential organs, such as the skin and those of the digestive tract, while epinephrine causes vasodilation in skeletal muscle and the heart. Thus blood is redistributed to those organs that will ready us for defense. Epinephrine also stimulates bronchodilation and increases heart rate, both of which optimize oxygen delivery to these organs. Both elevate blood glucose, and therefore provide the energy required for escape or defense.
